channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Open House
item.description: Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter for the answer.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: What Everyone's Arguing About: $$$ for College Athletes
item.description: The backstoryFor more than a century, the NCAA has governed one of the most cherished traditions in America: college sports. There are now college sports video games.  If that makes you go 🤔, then you'd probably be interested in the crucial Supreme Court case over college athlete compensation that kicked off last Wednesday. Nick Saban, the Alabama football coach, will make $9.5 million this year.   They are: Fans enjoy the product specifically because the athletes are amateurs, not paid professionals.  The other sideThe NCAA uses a few different arguments to defend its amateurism model. Athletes are paid in the form of a free college education that might cost others more than $60k a year.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Meme Battle: April 4
item.description: This week's meme is a classic we hooked from all the way down in Bikini Bottom.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Kate Noel, Head of People Ops at Morning Brew, Shares Advice with Readers
item.description: It's the happy medium that shows you take this interview seriously but also that you are cool enough to hire and be part of all the virtual company events to come. Can I wait until the morning to email her back?  My manager has a tendency to email me at 7–8pm, but I've been trying to keep a healthy work-life balance, which means closing my work laptop at 5:30pm.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 'Godzilla vs. Kong' Opened With a Boom, Netflix Bought 'Knives Out' Series
item.description: As more streaming services crowd consumers, Netflix has realized more seasons of Love is Blind just isn't enough to grow its subscriber base and sealed one of the biggest deals ever for the rights to a movie series.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Budget Airlines Signify a Boom for Industry
item.description: Frontier Airlines raised $570 million in an IPO yesterday, becoming the second budget airline (after Sun Country) to go public this year. US airports have recorded nearly three weeks of 1+ million daily passengers, and American Airlines said spring bookings are at 90% of 2019 levels.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Goldman Sachs, Google, and Amazon Prepare for Return to Office
item.description: Microsoft itself is already allowing some workers back, with part-time remote as the new standard.  Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser also plans on 3 days/week in the office for most employees after the pandemic.  Goldman Sachs told summer interns they're headed to TriBeCa.Wells Fargo told employees it's eyeing a return after Labor Day.Amazon said it's bringing Seattle HQ employees back in time for sweater weather. Moretti argues the pull of certain industries, packed bars, and Shawarma Guys is too strong for most people to work remote full-time in the long run.
item.author: Alex Hickey

Moretti argues the pull of industries in certain cities, packed bars, and Shawarma Guys is too strong for most people to work remote full-time in the long run.

item.title: Deliveroo Under-delivers In Its Stock Market Debut
item.description: Why the under-delivery?   Following a landmark court ruling, Uber recently said its UK drivers will receive a minimum wage and benefits, a concession that could set a precedent for the rest of the gig economy.  Looking ahead...

item.title: New York Becomes the 15th State to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: Two takeaways from NY’s Marijuana Regulation and Taxation Act1. New York’s cannabis economy is expected to become the second-biggest US market (just after Cali), generating billions in sales and $350 million in annual tax revenue once it fully lights up. Looking ahead... 2.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: 72 Black Executives Join the Fight to Protect Voting
item.description: Kenneth Chenault, former CEO of American Express, and Kenneth Frazier, CEO of pharma giant Merck, spearheaded a letter signed by 72 Black executives to oppose restrictive voting bills across the US, specifically the one passed in Georgia last Thursday. Civil rights activists took specific aim at Georgia-based companies that they felt were staying too quiet.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Biden Releases $2.3 Trillion Infrastructure Plan to Boost US Competitiveness and Combat Climate Change
item.description: Biden will introduce Part 2 of his economic spending proposal in the next few weeks, called the American Family Plan. To help pay for it, Biden wants to bump up the corporate tax from 21% to 28% and close other tax loopholes. For the climate, the plan “would be the most far-reaching federal investment to date in programs that would help curb greenhouse gas emissions,” writes Axios. $400 billion to caregiving efforts for the elderly and those with disabilities.  $650 billion to improve your life at home, like investments in high-speed broadband and the electric grid.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: New York Becomes the 15th State to Legalize Marijuana
item.description: New York’s cannabis economy is expected to become the second-biggest US market (just after Cali), generating billions in sales and $350 million in annual tax revenue once it fully lights up. Yesterday, NY Gov. Andrew Cuomo signed legislation legalizing the recreational use of marijuana by adults, making New York the 15th state to do so.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Morning Brew's 10 Most Popular Articles From the 1st Quarter
item.description: Business acronyms you should know  Here are Morning Brew's 10 most popular articles from this quarter. What's the hype around air fryers? The growing pet food industry9.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Morning Brew Writers Pick the Top Business News Story of Q1
item.description: To me, that's what made GameStop mania the biggest story of the quarter—the broader financial world was forced to acknowledge the power of social media users to move markets. It feels like we're in the early stages of so many emerging crypto applications and I'm excited for what's to come.   I'm hopeful that, as the rollout continues, businesses will be able to operate at full throttle and we can tentatively start seeing what this hyped New Normal thing is all about. The US has done a really good job—as of Tuesday, about 15% of Americans are fully vaccinated and we're on pace to administer 200 million shots in Biden's first 100 days.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Reader Q&A: What Is Financial Leverage?
item.description: The idea is to borrow money to make purchases that, over time, can make you far more money than your initial capital could.  In the financial world, investors use the term "leverage" to refer to debt that's used to fund transactions. But while leverage can increase your reward, it can also increase risk, which is where the story of this hedge fund, Archegos Capital Management, comes in.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 31
item.description: (The Cut)  Read: The therapy-app fantasy. The US and 13 other countries have also bashed the report, which concluded that bat → another animal → humans was the likeliest cause of the initial outbreak.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Home Prices Hit 7-Year High
item.description: Some experts think rising mortgage rates could cool the market. But as the pool of would-be buyers has grown, supply's gotten tighter than a Lower East Side kitchen: In February, available homes fell by nearly a third to just over 1 million.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Amazon Unionization Vote: Here's What to Watch
item.description: There's a close race to follow in Bessemer, AL, that decides whether or not 6,000 Amazon warehouse workers unionize. Union organizers may bring up Amazon's anti-union messaging campaign at the warehouse, which even followed workers into the bathroom. Plus, workers already get healthcare, vision, and dental benefits without paying union dues.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Cameo Becomes A Unicorn
item.description: Cameo is now valued at $1 billion after raising $100 million in Series C funding yesterday.    It's cantering with a growing herd of unicorns that focus on getting content from creators → fans with the least amount of friction possible. Platforms like Cameo and Substack were already getting more popular as fans sought out a more direct connection with creators, but the pandemic made backstage content = all content.  Also in 2020, the similar-but-significantly-more-NSFW platform OnlyFans made $300 million in profit on $400 million in revenue, per The Information.
item.author: Jamie Wilde
